articleContent.title: Chord: Dominant 7th in B (Shape: G)
articleContent.content:
# The Dominant 7th Chord in B (G Shape)

The Dominant 7th chord is made up of four notes: the root (B), major third (D#), perfect fifth (F#), and minor seventh (A). When played using the G shape on the guitar, it creates a distinctive sound due to the specific combination of intervals.

## Notes and Intervals
- Root: B
- Major Third: D#
- Perfect Fifth: F#
- Minor Seventh: A

## Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7th chord in B using the G shape has a strong and unresolved quality. It is often used to create tension and leads naturally to the tonic chord, creating a sense of anticipation and movement in music. This chord is commonly found in blues, jazz, and funk genres due to its characteristic sound.

## Example Songs
1. "Sweet Home Chicago" by Robert Johnson
2. "All Blues" by Miles Davis
3. "Superstition" by Stevie Wonder
